Then in colder climates, this would still hold true, but there far less creatures are venomous simply because it wasn't necessary to evolve the venomous trait.

First of all, antivenom can kill you as well. It can often cause aggressive allergic reaction. So, for most European venomous snakes, antivenom is given as a final resort. But they aren't nearly as venomous as Australian, tbh... Which brings us to the second point...
There are venomous snakes in Europe... And we do have harsh and cold winters here... During which snakes hibernate, but we do have those... Common European adder, for example (Vipera Berus) lives all over the place, can even be found in Great Britain and Finland. Small fangs, not much venom, purely hemotoxic... And probably the Europe's most venomous snake, nose-horned viper (Vipera ammodytes)... That's a but more nasty... Big fangs, plenty of venom, both hemotoxic and neurotoxic, but is a lethargic snake that hisses loudly to warn you of its presence and usually does dry bites... Either way, they are considered extremely dangerous for small animals, small children, old people and people with certain health issues. Antivenom is given, as said, as a last resort, when things do go bad...
But they do live in cold climates... Technically, hornets are venomous, and they live here, too (in fact, more people are killed by hornets here than by snakes; there hasn't been a single snake bite related death for decades)... But, I digress...

"They need a different strategy to survive, so many of them evolved Venom" WRONG!
That's really distorting the Theory of evolution, which seems to be a very common error.
The correct interpretation of Evolutionary theory is that "The ones that happened to have Venom mutations managed to survive better" its a small but VERY important distinction.
"so many of them evolved Venom" wrongly implies that evolution is a deliberate act instead of the actual lottery of mutations that it is.

Regardless of being cold-blooded (fact) or warm-blooded, creatures like snakes or spiders mutate to have venom by accident during their evolution history.  Is it possible that the responsible mutant is temperature sensitive?

Producing venom is an evolutionary cost on snakes because they would also have to spend a lot of immune system energy to flood themselves with antibodies to protect themselves from that venom.  If venom is not sufficiently useful, that immune system energy wasted is an evolutionary disadvantage.

Ugh....old video, but i have to say it, That was clumsily articulated.  To clarify better; A venomous creature delivers a toxin by, fangs, barbs, stinger, spines, or spurs ect. Poisonous creatures on the other hand, have toxins in their skin/body, blood maybe.  So yes, that would poison you if you ate them or absorbed toxins through your skin. But some poisonous animals just taste bad wile others may kill or make you sick.  Snakes, bees/wasps, caterpillars with barbs, Stone fish with its spines, Lion fish with their barbs, platypus with its spurs, spiders, scorpions, and many more are all venomous. Poisonous animals and plants include, poison arrow/dart frogs, blister beetles, monarch butterflies, hooded pitohui(bird) and plants like poison oak. So thar ya go. For anyone looking up this topic, or somehow stumbling here, i hope that gives a clear picture.

What I'm wondering is that the different humans react very different to most of those venoms. Even those pronounced deadly can often be survived - though in most cases that takes hospital aid. However I know of a person who claims to have been bitten by a black widow (relative of the redback) and a brown recluse at different occasions without major effects. Ok, there was a great amount of pain involved, but nothing else. Also there's that weird story out there of a man who has repeatedly been bitten by different redbacks when using public toilets. He, too, is still alive (or so the story goes).
I'm happy to live in an area where no dangerous venomous creatures exist. But for all I've gathered, knowing how to act once you've "received" the venom makes a whole lot of difference as to how it turns out. Next absolutely weird thing I've heard is that bites of young snakes tend to be more dangerous than the bites of the old ones because the old ones have learned to "calculate" the dose of venom for a defensive bite and don't intend to kill you while the young ones only bite without any control of the venom. That's so amazing and there's so much to learn and marvel at. Still prefer to live in a non-venomous environment :)

It looks like this is a great example of a spurios correlation.  Higher temperature means more venomous animals.  But the higher temperature is resulting in more ectotherms. As most venomous animals are ectotherms, we see the association and assume it is the causation.

Another idea: Being venomous is only a good survival strategy when the venomous species are few among many other nonvenomous species. They advertise their venomosity, if that is a word, by being distinctively colored or having rattles on their tails, so predators can easily learn to avoid them. This strategy works well in the tropics with its many species, but wouldn't work at all in the arctic where there are big populations but few different species. There the absence of enough other prey species would compel the predator species to evolve venom immunity.  The same reasoning may apply to the question of why species in the tropics are more colorful than species in cold climates: it's only an effective strategy, either for avoiding predation or for finding mates, when there are many different species.

I have a theory that looks at this in another way. Instead of looking at only why are they NOT in cold environments, let's look for why WOULD venomous creatures evolve in cold environments as well. The first idea is that the evolutionary pressures of adapting to surviving the colder climates, and the seasonal hibernation or hatching reset of many species didn't' leave much energy resources or need for many highly venomous creatures. It seems there are plenty of poisonous creatures in colder environments, but that is more of a passive projection that protects a species not an individual.
Nor is it as helpful in feeding because of the basic hunting strategies employed in a colder environment.
I surmise that venom turns out to be not as useful in colder areas. As a hunter in the cold, you do not have the time for venom to work or to make that "soup" when it's more imperative to stay warm and not become a meal for another cold hungry creature.

Venom is a good weapon IF you can deploy it, and then be able to store the food for later. However this is not possible in the cold because once the food freezes, unless you can manipulate fire, the food is frozen and uneatable. If a venom usefulness in part it so digest the food, this is again a failure point as it will freeze. If venom had antifreeze property THEN venom would be very beneficial in cold environments. But how many bio compatible chemicals are there that can work when it is well under the temperature of freezing?

One could envisage that the venomous spittle is the result of an exclusively exocrine activity strictly confined to this excretory tract ( that is not born out by facts since apparently (meaning to my very faillible knowledge ) many are the result of a concentration process based on a poisonous criters based diets) . Even if such an assumption where true we would be left with a problem :
A venomous saliva specie will not in ordinary circumstances be prone to poisoning by it's own venom , but would it be immune to its injection or its accidental injection such as an even minor digestive tract injury ?

there is still an indirect kind of causation between venom and temperature in the way that evolving towards venom inherently synergizes with cold blooded creatures: Biochemically speaking they dont have great reserves of energy and have much less stamina, it only makes sense to hunt by ambush->one bite -> walk to where prey is dying and hope you can recover it. It's not the most efficient way of hunting, a lot of the time the prey will get away to where you cannot consume them but the energy investment made was very little and you didnt even have to leave your warm spot.
Compared to hot blooded creatures with our sweet fat cells and livers giving us nice stores of energy and efficient ATP reactions so we can actually chase a prey down, kill it by repeatedly biting: all very much not efficient but we have a very high rate of securing the prey. Would make sense because that prey is your only source of energy for the entire winter, when your body is already burning insane amounts of energy just to stay on a living temperature.

"You would need to keep injecting yourself with the venom... every month."
This is what beekeepers with allergies do to stay safe. Venom is collected (from China mostly, which is a political/economical issue among beekeepers) and dosed out carefully in the lab. A small amount of the venom dust can kill anyone at the high concentrations it's collected at. Then it's dosed out for people trying to reduce the severity of their allergy reaction. Some beekeepers will sting themselves intentionally if they aren't stung for a month, but it can be dangerous when done like that. Many beekeepers will even develop an allergy over time if they aren't stung enough or don't get their venom shots. The body needs the immune response in the blood for the beekeeper to keep working in the environment with the bees. Frequently breathing even small quantities of venom over time, which is scattered around the hive, will exacerbate the immune system response when a sting occurs.

I rarely see them and I’ve NEVER seen a funnel web except once when it was at the bottom of a swimming pool. I’ve spent most of my life in Sydney and although I’ve worked in offices I do have friends that live in house with gardens that sometimes back up onto a national park.

Australians always big note themselves in pubs about Australia having animals that just want to kill you because it makes them look like some sort of Crocodile Dundee (he’s just trying to get laid and that’s HIS angle) - in truth we mostly don’t see any of these animals unless we work in the bush or as a landscape gardener. ....also - sure you can bandage a snake bite but just think, you’re probably hiking and most people’s hearts are racing at 130-180 beats per minute when it happens...and you have to keep it immobilised....your also probably an hour away from the nearest car park so your chances don’t look good. You better have a friend who can run really fast because in a couple of hours you’re going to be dead and you have to lay down and stay still and rest - you’re not going anywhere - (you’ve probably been walking for the last couple of hours)...and before you die you’re going to feel about as sick as you’ve ever felt in all your life. His answer remains correct but I think an important scientific point is that venoms likely evolved through some kind of chemical arms race. For obvious reasons such arms races are more common if there is a high competition between species for a single ecological niche and due to the fact that there are more species in hotter regions this gives a more probable mechanism. In colder regions the fight against the environment, thus the climate alone likely kept competition between species to a minimum, making specialized adaptations like venoms less important.

Venom is poison. The distinction for poison and venom terms is used in medicine and zoology, which is use for treatment or classifying the route of effect (delivery method), respectively. Trying to 'correct' someone with the term venom is equivalent to 'correcting' someone who calls a black mamba a black mamba by saying "that is not a black mamba, that is dendroaspis polylepis".
Also route of effect differs even in absorbed poisons, such as you can have castor beans (ricin) in your hands and not get sick or die, but the same beans if eaten could be deadly. While dimethylmercury is readily absorbed in the skin and is extremely deadly even through skin absorbtion. That being said, getting venom in the eye, will still cause harm and it is not injected.
The delivery method (route of effect) is very important in medicine for the medical professionals to treat the patient, however the medical professionals know if someone says that they got bit by a poisonous snake, they know that it is a venomous snake.

I don't agree with the conclusion.
It seems, by various reasons given by the scientists interviewed, that there are actually more venomous animals in warm climates because:
- venomous animals are mostly ectotherm and they are more likely to survive, thrive and evolve in warm weather.
- colder places have been "wiped out" from ectotherms in the last ice age.

So, it seems to me that the fact of being cold blooded makes temperature a great factor for survival and specialization of venomous animals. Of course, it could be pointed out that above a certain temperature there's no improvement in survival with each incremental degree, or even that above a critical temperature their survival might be affected.

Why?
Nutrient density in the flora.

OK, the snake thing!
Hotter climes have less calories laying around, that means predators have to look farther for meals and balance calories expended against calories gained.
A quick bite and a squirt of venom and there is your hot lunch. Very little calories invested and being venomous often comes with markings to warn off competition.
There is simply less to eat in hotter climates than in temperate ones, so predation has to be very efficient.

Primates did not build immunity to snake venom/insect venom probably because exposure was very less during evolution. Snakes don't want to waste venom on things they cannot ingest. So probably avoided biting large animals. Venom production is energy intensive business.

Primates were more in danger from constrictors. Constrictors are able to ingest large prey and regularly hunt monkeys, lemurs and other primates up in trees. Human/ape babies were probably on their list. Livestock certainly was. And thus primates developed instinctive fear of all snakes.

Getting bitten because we stepped on a snake or handled it incorrectly is not the same as being actively targeted by venomous snakes as prey.

Again, human body also does not waste energy building and maintaining immunity for something it may never get exposed to all its life.

Energy efficiency is key for survival. All life operates around that principle. It also might provide answer for distribution of venomous species.

my reason for why australia has the most venomous snakes is because opportunities for snakes to eat don't happen as often as in other continents and some of the animals can cover large distances more easily.  eg. kangaroos aren't the only australian creature that has that efficient method of movement called hopping.  there is a subspecies of tiger snake that lives on chappell island and it has evolved to survive on one short period of the year when there is food on the island-nesting birds.  probably something along this line for some of the spiders. i can't think of a reason for why australian seas have such incredibly venomous jellyfish.  and the most dangerous creature in tasmania isn't a devil, its a jumping ant.  i found a safety brochure from america that mentioned that if you were to get stung by the barbs of a particular fish you should apply hot water, as hot as you can stand, to the affected area.  it disables the proteins.  egg proteins are disabled by heating-the white goes white and the yolk goes hard.  all venoms are protein-based.  i live here.  i'll be putting hot water on any bite or sting immediately after calling the ambulance.

Here's my answer: 1. Because most venomous animals mainly hunt coldblooded prey. In warm regions the blood of coldblooded animals is... well err... less cold which makes the chemical reactions venom is based on take place faster and with greater effect... Meaning prey dies faster and the hunter can avoid their prey escaping or even wounding them more often.
2. Tropical rainforests and coral reefs occur only in warm climates and house a huge chunk of the worlds species in general (venomous or not).
3. Venom usually evolves to effectively hunt only a handful of very specific prey species; venom is often a specialist survival strategy. Tropical rainforests and coral reefs have far more specialist species than any other type of environment in nature.

Just wanted to throw this out there. I had a clutch of copperheads born in captivity unexpectedly. Copperheads like most vipers do not lay eggs but have "live birth" (Ovoviviparity). Before the 14 babies where able to be separated, about 1/3 where dead due to bites from their litter mates. They where very nippy at anything that moved and being in such close proximity to one another, they where nipping each other and envenomating each other. One might think that a snake is immune to its own venom but that is not the case. This might be the reason snakes have evolved away from having venom, it can also be dangerous to the animal carrying the venom. Brings a whole new meaning to biting your lip. While other snakes like King Snakes have evolved immunities to venomous snakes so they can prey on them, yet are not venomous themselves.
Shortly, blood flows faster when its warm, and venom benefits off better blood flow.

'Why Do Venomous Animals Live In Warm Climates?' Saw this long ago, and came back up looking in history and it hit me that it could be simply and exactly that, 'Warm Climates'. Same reason ambush hunting is an advantage, so is venom. Both shorten the chase, capture, kill energy expenditure, which is far more important to do in a warmer climate than a cooler one.
Overheating is not only bad for the predator and may lead to an escape, the prey overheating may also reduce the quality of the prey as a food item. The long term investment and energy expenditure of making venom is easier to control than a chase, and can be done in the non-critical waiting down time without risking overheating.
In a cooler climate you have muscle heating and insulation, and a bit longer chase may actually be beneficial to staying more fit and successful overall. That could make too effective venom into a drawback long term, and it would be quickly reduced or lost.

The areas with lower temperatures are more inhabited by humans, thus there are less venomous creatures in these areas because the humans living in the areas clear them out. Of course there are exceptions as in Australia where more humans choose to live in the northern region rather than the southern region, thus the reason why there are more venomous creatures in the southern region, and India where there are a lot of densely populated urban areas lacking the means to rid the area of these venomous creatures. You must consider causation versus correlation. There is, in a broad sense, a correlation between the amount of venomous creatures living in an area and the temperature of these areas being rather high, yet this may not be the cause of this phenomenon. However, as science moves forward we will grasp a far greater insight on the topic.

My guess, warm areas consistently have higher number of species, this means that predators are going to be attacking and consuming a wider variety of species, and each prey species is predated on by a wider variety of predators.  This prevents any prey species from evolving immunity to the venom because they would need to be immune to a large number of venom types, allowing the venom based strategy to be effective.  Once a venomous creature is the only one in it's environment then it's much easier for the prey to develop resistance, this is similar to the anti-biotic resistance problem. Why are non venomous snakes more successful than venomous species? I have a theory for this, and I believe it would have to do with success rate versus opportunity. A bite doesn't always mean a kill, since the prey still has a chance to get away (it will still probably die, but may be inaccessible). Venomous species usually only have one shot since they have to take time to build the venom up again, giving them a smaller window of opportunity versus something like a constrictor that can just go hunting again. Prey that escapes or having to defend itself takes away from that window of opportunity, giving other species a chance to hunt when the venomous snake cannot. Using their one shot to defend itself also leaves the venomous snake more vulnerable to predation since it cannot defend itself. In short, venomous species can have a higher success rate, but their window of opportunity is much smaller.

Im an evolutionary expert. There's more biodiversity in "Tropical" places, hence there's more variety of everything, even venomous animals. The question is "why is there more biodiversity in the tropics?". Because it's the most stable climate with temps that only fluctuate ~ 14C (25F) in the entire year, vs temps that fluctuate  ~45C (80F) outside the tropics. That increased biodiversity compounds the evolutionary effect by increasing competitiveness among species forcing them to evolve more aggressive traits. Invasive Fire ants for example are from the tropics & they are highly evolved outcompeting all ants outside the tropics in climates they can tolerate. There is more than a trend, you’re just asking the wrong people. For places like Hawaii it’s likely the ecosystem wasn’t diverse enough to warrant the evolution of venom. Example would be something along the lines of birds, a snake really doesn’t need venom to kill a bird, so any snake that evolved venom wouldn’t have a particular advantage and most likely not pass down its genes. In fact I can see a disadvantage since to create venom requires energy. It’s all about the calories.

To continue what my first sentence, the people to ask would be the chemists and physicists. Looking at a compound’s formulation, it’s obviously and endothermic reaction ( it takes heat and energy to create). If you’re a wolf in the Arctic for example and trying to survive, it wouldn’t make a lot of sense to have a continual process stealing precious calories when eventually evolution produces something requiring less, say, sharp teeth...

As for the biologists saying there is no pattern, that is complete nonsense. In North America for example there is a specific line where nothing north of the line produces venom ( at a macro level, not aware of microscopic organisms and such). This line is slightly north of Washington D.C. , and they have it nailed down pretty well and exceptions are extremely rare, all essentially strays but never more than 100km or so north. For those curious, the animal is a rattlesnake, which isn’t particularly venomous comparative to others of the same species found in California or Texas for example.

As for Australia, going off the word of the biologists and how the snake was introduced makes sense, it also doesn’t break the trend for poison being in warmer places. Southern Australia may be colder than northern Australia, but it’s hardly cold baby global standards. What’s the temperature range for Sydney? Between 18-28 all year? Something like that?

My professors gave an explanation not too dissimilar to your conclusion with some added details.  Colder climates typically have lower biodiversity and competition for resources.  With increased competition for resources, there is evolutionary pressure to have stronger offenses (venom) and defenses (poison) against prey and predators, respectively.  In areas where animals are just as likely to die from cold or starvation as a predator, evolution favors adaptations that protect from the environment as well as evasion of predators and capture of prey.  This simple splitting of pressures and reduction of available resources causes the lower rates of specialized species which can include those with chemical weapons.

Being Australian, I have often wondered about this, especially because Australia doesn't really have any big predators.so why did all these crazy venomous creatures evolve? My conclusion is that in a hot place like Australia, moving around is detrimental because it wastes energy and means you're in direct sunlight. That's why there aren't a lot of big animals. In a lot of the places where these venomous creatures live, most of their prey are lizards and other cold blooded animals. This means that if you're a snake, or spider, or whatever, then you not only want to exert as little energy as possible yourself, you also have to make sure that when prey comes by you don't fail to kill it. This makes powerful venom a huge advantage. If you're venomous but your venom isn't very strong, then the creature you inject will get further before gong down. Furthermore in hot climates heart rate is lower, so the venom will move around the body slower, and needs to be stronger as a result. I think the heat means that running after prey is not good for a predator, and it's not good for the prey either, so both have evolved away from that. I could be completely and utterly wrong, but those are my thoughts...

"We're living in a particular point in time" is honestly a very valuable observation when talking about "why things are the way they are", that a lot of people seem to overlook. Just because something has been happening for a while, or history has worked out a certain way, doesn't make the status quo an immutable law of nature - and claims that "the way things are" is "the natural order of things" have been used to justify all sorts of horrible social evils.

It's also interesting that you mentioned saliva, so snakes actually secrete saliva? I don't think so. Saliva itself is a form of Gastric juices used to break down specific compounds in the food we eat. snakes swallow their meals whole, and do not chew, so the introduction of saliva into a snake's form of eating would be useless, and in fact could be detrimental, because saliva can find it's way into breathing tubes and the tube for a snakes lungs is in its mouth, where the saliva would need to be also, so the snake would have to hold it's breath while chewing, and we already know snakes do not have molars, so saliva is out. Saliva could also increase the snakes chances for dehydration as well. So venom might be only as expensive to make as saliva, but snakes produce no saliva, there are of course mucosa in the snakes mouth that need moisture, and that is just plain moisture most likely from the tissue itself. Saliva and venom, venom stays in glands until it is needed, saliva wouldn't work nor would it be of any benefit for the snake, I'm afraid.

Interesting video, but I think more attention needs to be paid to the fallacies contained in your initial questions and definitions, specifically the idea that "venomous" means "deadly to humans", as opposed to simply "utilizes venom". Lots of creatures that are harmless or mostly-harmless to humans still use venom that's very effective on their prey, which is the primary purpose of venom to begin with. Defining "venomous" in relation to humans means ignoring that relationship, for no real reason; as you mentioned with the funnel-web, lots of "deadly-to-human" venoms seem to have that characteristic entirely by accident, as the creatures possessing said venom don't count primates as major prey or predators. Interesting discussion to be had here about the dangers of over-assumptions around humanity's centrality in the natural world. Most of the time, it just ain't about us, and we don't like to remember that too often.

Regarding the point about venom production being roughly-equivalent to saliva production; are you sure about that? I've heard a lot of behaviour of venomous creatures (ie "dry bites", etc.) explained with the idea that venom is very expensive in time and calories to produce, which would seem to make sense on a number of levels. If it were only as expensive as saliva, wouldn't creatures use it as freely as humans do saliva? We spit *everywhere*.

Looking at North American snake species, the % that are venomous decreases the further north you go, but  this may ironically be due in part to the venomous species need to cope, NOT with heat, but with the relatively COLD ground level temperatures at night throughout the arid S.W. regions of the U.S.  In pursuit of their heat-avoiding, (i.e.nocturnal) prey, rattlesnakes need to somehow remain active during sub-optimal temperatures, despite lacking the advantage their quarry enjoys being warm-blooded.  Rattlers' much stouter bodies (compared to the sleeker forms of non-venomous N.A, species) allows for greater heat retention during the cold of desert nights, and together with an energy-saving ambush strategy, and fast-acting venom to reduce  energy costs of subduing dinner, all combine to meet the challenge of extreme temperature fluctuations. These conditions almost preclude non-venomous species in these regions, but this v to non-v ratio quickly reverses  moving further north and east. I'm guessing this is because greater vegetative  cover reduces day to night temp. swings thus removing those severe activity  restrictions for prey and predator alike. In fact I suspect that in North America, rainfall or vegetative ground cover are far better predictors of the % of venomous snake species than temperature alone.

I have my suspicions that the issue is also one of metabolism and seasonal survival. Larger animals that survive the winter without hibernation must be hunters. Sitting around as an ambush predator doesn't work well in winter. If you're not using ambush, venom is not too important - you're pursuing your meal and need to get a good handle on it to get venom into it.. If you can pursue and take it down, though, you don't need venom! You already have the ability to kill.

What about smaller predators, like insects? Well, two things. Larger insects survive in warmer temperatures. That seems purely seasonal driven. It's harder to become a deadly "venomous" spider or scorpion when your dose is irrelevant. I wonder if you normalize dose sizes inversely to latitude, the density of envenoming predators gets closer to an even spread across latitudes.

I've only gotten to 2:19 so far, but I think I have the answer and I think it's super simple. But, maybe it's not as simple and obvious as I think it is, so I'm going to put my explanation here before I continue watching, then I'll go on to see if I'm a smarty pants or dip sht :). Here goes: warmer climates produce more life, period. They are much more conducive overall to life itself - for instance, leave a piece of meat out in 40 degree F weather, then try 80 degree F - you'll quickly see how much easier it is for organisms to reproduce (by how quickly the meat rots, which is simply decomposition by way of micro organisms) and therefore, more vegetation = more food = larger populations that thrive = more opportunity for evolution = greater number of species = more fine tuned skills needed for survival = greater number of species that have very specialized ways of competing for food and succeeding. Now let's see if it's that simple... On to watch the rest.

Ok, so after watching, it seems maybe the original hypothesis that there are more venomous species in warm climates may not even be true. I think the venomous question is probably the same... There really are many logical reasons as to why things are the way they are. Still, the main thing to keep in mind is really that there are more animals to keep track of in warmer climates, and chances are that more of them are venomous simply due to the sheer amount.

This is misleading. Ectotherms have a far greater tendency toward carrying venom than endotherms because they don't have the metabolic capacity to chase down their prey. Ectotherms also tend toward warmer climates, again because of heat metabolism. So venomous animals do indeed appear in greater amounts in hotter areas, but this correlation disappears entirely when controlling for ectotherm quantity because of the specific reason why the correlation appears in the first place.

Humans are a selection pressure too and that could explain the loss of venom. Certain birds in North America have evolved shorter wing spans allowing more agile flight and in turn allowing them to take advantage of highway overpasses for nesting. The birds with longer wing spans kept getting hit by cars. This has been confirmed by examining the bodies of birds killed in this manner near these nesting sites. The birds with shorter wingspans are at this point nearly absent from the impacted population despite representing the majority of the birds at these sites. This data set goes back several decades and actually traces the development of the shorter wingspan over time. Rattlesnakes in North America are beginning to not use their rattles. Why? Because we humans like to eliminate things that can kill us or display aggression towards us. While many snakes go unseen by simply waiting for us to walk on by these rattlesnakes would basically announce their presence every time we were near. The rattle is still there. They just don't use it nearly as often as they once did. Along the same lines it is not hard to imagine our ancestors doing this over thousands of years. Something proves to be a threat and we hunt it down - and anything that looks like it. As such venom and aggression became a liability anywhere you find humans and we are everywhere. This wouldn't be a hard and fast rule with an absolute effect but it is still a selection pressure.

Lots of problems with his explanation. First, without realizing it, he actually restricts his inquiry to animals that are sufficiently venomous to kill a person, but most venomous animals cannot kill a person. Because he has missed the illogic in his focus he is trying to answer the wrong question.

In fact, most or nearly all spider species are venomous, but not nearly enough to endanger a human. Now venom must be biologically expensive. So, the question arises naturally, why should a spider or a snake ever have powerful enough venom to kill a person? An animal as large as a person is far too large to be prey, so the only possible reason would be defensive. But even lethal venoms are rarely powerful enough to kill a large animal instantaneously and so would not offer much protection, for instance, against being stepped on by a horse. In fact, in most species whose venom is powerful enough to kill a person, the venom capacity developed to overcome a much smaller preferred target prey animal, such as a rodent in the case of a snake. But then the rodent develops some resistance to the snake's venom and an evolutionary arms race ensues as the snake's venom becomes progressively more potent to overcome the heightened resistance of the mouse. It is just an unfortunate, for us, and coincidental byproduct of this process that the snake's venom is strong enough kill a person or a horse.

So, then why would there be more such powerfully venomous animals in the hot countries than in the temperate regions? Well, the predator-prey arms race of venom and resistance takes time to evolve. The ecosystems in the temperate region, however, were mostly wiped out in the last ice age and so are only about 15,000 years old, too short time in terms of evolution for such complexity to evolve. The ecosystems of the hot countries are much older and considerably more complex including, but not only, with respect to these predator-prey relationships.

The explanation of the original immigration of venomous snakes to Australia twenty million years ago, does not explain the prevalence of venom-capacity in Australian snake species today. We know that venom-production has disappeared over time for some species of snakes consistent with our expectation of high-cost. If venom capacity offered little survival advantage for the invasive species in Australia there would have been enough time for it to evolve away during twenty million years, but it hasn't.

The cost of producing venom may not be high, but maintaining the pieces of DNA that code for it up to date (particularly given that the targets of the venom evolve as well (see Red Queen Effect)) and avoiding code rot means evolution cannot focus as much "attention" on other traits. Perhaps it's the heat and the land area. In warmer places, the trend tends to be that animals need less fat to stay warm and need to be more compact to accommodate for faster metabolisms requiring them to be smaller and faster to gather more food compared to their weight. So, say we have a snake that is placed globally. Regardless of ecto or endothermal properties, if the snake is an average size of a few feet, it's going to have more luck getting food when it is smaller. With a few exceptions in terms of size, fat regardless, being things such as elephants in the warmer climates, you're more than likely going to find more things such as small prairie mice such as a titmouse (Not saying you're going to find mice infestations, but smaller animals in general) which are easier for the snake to catch and consume. So, the populations in climates that are not in these warmer zones with easier to catch and consume prey are going to die out, leaving the ones in warmer climates to prosper. Land area comes into play just because of the room that these populations have to sustain themselves in relation to their prey. Obviously a place such as australia or North America will have a larger population than ireland or jamaica. Jaimaica is irrelevantly tiny in comparison. One population will die out as it overconsumes and overreproduces in comparison to how much room the population has to dilute itself.

As a student of Creation Science, I find your observations interesting, but I disagree with many of your conclusions.

However, I want to point out a common error that I find evolutionists consistently make. If you listen to your statement beginning at 8:15 until 8:25 you will see that you make a statement that effectively says the following: "The species had a need, therefore they evolved a solution."

My friend, that is not evolution. Random chance mutations are not planned strategies to solve a problem. That statement is far more sympathetic to Intelligent Design.

Random mutations are exactly that -- random. They are not a volitional act to improve the species' chances of natural selection. While it is possible that a random mutation might be an improvement to previous organisms, we know from science that more often than not, mutations have a negative impact on organisms. In fact, it is just as likely that mutations would have produced a second head or a new enzyme capable of digesting alternative foods. But the notion that species,
snakes for instance, would so fortuitously manage to produce a venom by mere chance mutation is so infinitesimal as to defy logic. And all the more so that it was done in response to the comparison with other animals that had superior adaptions.

I have a thought on the disadvantages of venom -- it's risky.  If you're producing venom, either you have to be immune to it (which is tricky, especially if you have one of the really useful kinds of venom that targets, say, the most common / efficient / evolutionarily advantageous system for distributing blood, which would mean you have to settle for a less efficient system), or you have to contain it somehow (like in a venom sac), and if you go with that then you have to be careful not to jab yourself with the delivery mechanism.  And since these are animals, who have to carry their venom and its delivery mechanism around with them 24/7 (unlike a human, who could put the poisoned dagger in a box when they're not using it), that can be a significant risk.  Want to get around that risk?  You'll need specialized structures, like fang covers that only retract when your teeth are out of range of the rest of your mouth or that only release your fangs when your lower jaw is way out of the way, and that means you're more complex and take more energy to produce offspring.  Failing that, you'll need specialized behavioural programming, which can be even more complex (and more finicky and less reliable).  So even if making venom doesn't impose all that much of an energy cost on the individual snake compared to just making saliva, having the genetic coding to produce venom imposes a cost on the species that may or may not be worth it.  This is also probably why you get successful non-venomous snakes evolving from venomous ones -- like you said, venomous snakes have venom so they can be less active, and only operate in short bursts of activity that reliably kill their prey outright.  So a non-venomous snake has to be more physically active than a venomous one -- and since they're not using the energy to build each offspring with venom equipment, they can put that energy into muscles and bones instead.  And an increased capacity for physical activity can offer some advantages over being venomous (though obviously not an absolute / universal advantage, or else venomous snakes would never have evolved to begin with).  So if some combination of external factors shifts the balance away from venom in some significant way -- maybe the kind of large, nutritious prey that venomous snakes are used to feeding on become scarce, and they start needing to go hunting more often for smaller prey -- it makes sense that some lineage that traded super-deadly venom for increased physical abilities would find itself at an advantage.

Some time ago i read an explanation why inland taipans are so venomous, it is in the evolution and natural selection of two species. The inland taipan and, 'its main food source', a type of mice. Its like an arms race between the resistance of the mice and the potency of the venom of the taipan. The mice build up a resistance over thousands of years, meaning that the taipans  with the most potent were the ones to survive. Also mice with the strongest resistance lived on. This 'cycle' goes on and on, making the inland taipan more venomous and the mice more potent to its venom.

It was recently discovered that ALL SNAKES ARE VENOMOUS. As alluded to in this video, the species we previously considered "non-venomous" have very weak venom or have evolved very weak to useless methods to envenomate their prey. Evolutionarily speaking this is similar to the Kiwi having wings but being unable to fly. We've also recently discovered that some other species have venom which were previously thought not to - the Komodo dragon, for instance, has recently been discovered to kill their prey with a venom when it was previously thought to just be a particularly unhealthy set of bacteria in their mouths which infected the wounds they inflict.

So rattlesnakes are venomous and they live in cool climates. Black widows also live in cool climates. The simple facts are these:
1. The vast majority of organisms live in warmer climates. There is more plant material in warm locales (in part due to temperature, but also due to average annual sunlight, etc.) and thus a stronger base for the food chain. Cooler climates have dormant seasons and thus less plant material.
2. Most venomous species are reptiles, with very few exceptions, and, being cold-blooded, they survive better in warmer climates.

I'd also wager that if you compared venomous species to all species for a given climate that you would find the ratios to be the same for warm and cold regions. In other words, the number of venomous species is directly proportional to the number of species overall.

I have a theory. Warmer climate tend to have higher energy flux through them and tend to be more productive environments.
In ecology there is the resistance/resilience and competitive ability tradeoff. Animals evolve to either be good at living in harsh environment or at competing with other species, this explains how in rivers animals that are less able to compete can still persist (due to disturbance such as flood and drought).
Perhaps the high productivity and energy availability in warmer regions lends itself to evolving venom as it is a competitive trait.

I would guess that we kill more of the snakes that we identify as venomous than we do of the snakes that we identify as not venomous.  Some identified as venomous will start to lose venom creating ability naturally over time, but testing doesn't include all venomous snakes, only a random few.  Some identified as non-venomous would likely also start creating venom, but testing there is likely even more seldom tested due to it's perceived lesser threat level.  It's possible that an equal number of venomous and non-venomous snakes are killed on principle alone, making it even more challenging to verify any venom production trends.  It's fun to speculate, but I venture the amount of testing to prove any of this would not be feasible.

Maybe the answer to the question "Why non-venomous snakes evolve from venomous ones" is that venom is just not necessary. It allows a small animal to kill a much larger one, but a snake can not chew, so it can't eat it. The prey of a reptile has to be small, so a strong venom is not a necessity to kill it. The snake can just overpower it with its strength and bite, and so non-venomous species evolve and succeed along with venomous ones.  Venom is a great defensive mechanism, allowing the snake to defend its nest, but non-venomous species may develop a higher reproduction rate to compensate for opportunistic nest poaching mammals, and in the long term, out-populate the venomous species thanks to that.

Venom is the 'lazy kill'.
Not much energy requirement in producing toxins, huge energy requirements in active hunting.
Warm climates do not produce food with high energy content [lots of carbs and some calories, very little fat/protein], hot weather favors smaller animals.  Net result is that predators use venom rather than speed, strength or claws.

There is no answer for the platypus.  I think they are just showing off.

Most enzymes work only within a narrow temperature range. You will notice that many venomous creatures are cold blooded, I.E. they can not control their temperature range. Warm blooded creatures CAN control their temperature range, which as you might guess, is warm. You will also notice that venomous creatures can not control the temperature of their target. The target is either going to match the temperature of its surroundings (which can vary wildly), or it's going to have a warm interior with a known temperature.

Now let's do a simple thought experiment. We have four small, cold blooded creatures. Two of them live in a hot climate, and two live in a cold climate. Of each of these pairs one of them has an enzyme based venom that is fully active at hot temperature, while the other's venom is active at low temperature. Which creature is the most dangerous?

- The hot climate creature with the cold venom is screwed. It can't do anything because the local temperature never reaches a point where the venom can work. Darwin wins.

- The cold climate creature with the hot venom is in a lot of trouble. It can only envenom warm blooded creatures, which tend to be larger or faster or riskier targets. Some warm blooded creatures will even hibernate, causing trouble in winter. The odds are stacked against this creature.

- The cold climate creature with cold venom is okay. It can tackle other cold blooded targets in its class, but it can not do much to endanger a warm target because the venom turns inert as it warms up. There is more benefit to specializing its venom against other cold blooded targets, rather than developing an ENTIRELY NEW venom just to deal with something warm.

- The hot climate creature with the hot venom is WINNING. Its venom is fully active against cold blooded creatures, who must suffer the same high temperatures as their environment. It can also apply the SAME venom to warm blooded animals, who will keep the venom active in their blood stream. Every new evolution of venom has the potential to improve its diet, dramatically increasing its access to food.

So there you have it. Venom preference is a simple matter of chemistry.

1. There are less species overall in colder climates than the tropics. Simple matter of more photosynthesis, more plants, more food, more animals near the equator. Mexico might have a 40+ toxic species but that is still out of hundreds of thousands of species. Meanwhile... northern Canada only has a few thousand species total.

2. Most venomous animals are snakes and insects. Neither do well in cold climates since they are cold-blooded. Insects rely on other insects for food... and (above).

3. Most animals in northern climates have developed thick hides and thick fatty layers under their hides. These do not contain large amounts of blood vessels and are extremely poor at conducting venoms. A cobra could bite a polar bear all day and likely never get enough poison into one to do anything.

4. Many northern animals already have slow metabolisms. This makes spreading toxins more difficult and makes many forms of toxins which attack the heart less likely to work. Many animals can already continue functioning despite extremely slow heart and circulatory systems. Cold also constricts blood vessels and freezes blood... making coagulant toxins much less effective.

5. Many northern animals have developed size as a defense against cold.

Here's my theory behind it all. Perhaps the less food a snake comes across over time, and the greater the temperature is in their environment, the more crucial it becomes for the snake to kill something. Maybe it also has to do with how they kill their prey as well. Pythons simply constrict and perhaps bite = no venom while the smaller less strong snakes rely on venom. If their prey are tougher to deal with, then the snake's genes may register this information from previous failed encounters, and this may in return buff its venom strength to compensate. I strongly believe it has to do with an underlying balance between all things both good and bad [or positive and negative].

Being in warm climate as opposed to cold climate = good; therefore, the counterbalance to said "good" = more venomous creatures = bad. In the cold, you have to worry more about surviving frostbite, starvation, etc. = bad; therefore, the counterbalance to said "bad" = less venomous creatures. Venomous creatures that kill prey that're larger than them may help feed the larger creatures that may be having a hard time catching food. Call it God's freebie. It may also help provide some anti-venom if the venom information is transferred from the dead animal slain by it over to the animal consuming the free meal. Just my two cents, and my personal belief in the matter. None of what I say is proven fact; it's all just my own personal theory. I simply believe that there's an incredibly balanced mind behind it all.

To me the obvious answer to this question is that warmer climates lead to more dense ecosystems with more fauna and flora. Because of this there is more competition between species and therefore more extreme adaptations for survival (like being venomous). Also, since there are more animals and plants in these climates, there is a higher chance of venomous animals.

Well, in a sense evolution is fine as an explanation (because what isn't tied to evolution when we are talking about existence of different species?). Environmental factors are one of the biggest driving forces behind evolution. 

Snakes and spiders for one, have the same kind of long history, where the earliest species of such animals have been in a situation, which has helped/forced them to create venom.

Snakes are cold-blooded (as already explained) and they need warmth to get their body temperature to a right degree. This is easier in climates where there is more sun, and as such, more heat. There are European vipers here in Finland too for example, but once winter and the cold arrives, they go into dark places inside crevices for example, and go into a state of brumation, which is a state similar to hibernation, but the two aren't the same thing.

Now with spiders on the other hand there is little or no tolerance to cold. Most of the spiders die during the winter. Some bigger spiders like tarantulas, who have longer life-spans, need some kind of shelter (like snakes) like under a tree bark or inside a house where they can do their hibernation (again, not really hibernation, but of something of their own design).

On a much broader sense there is a rule which dictates that warmer climates can support more species per an area of specified size, compared to the same sized area of a colder climate. This has probably more to do with plants at this point more than anything else. Heat and rainfall dictate growing seasons on plants, and where there is more abundance of such things, the growing season is longer and more species of plants can thrive (it can't be too hot or humid of course). So plants need these things, animals eat plants, and other animals eat the other animals. Everybody is happy, and the plentiful supply of food attracts more animals.

Evolution then does what it does. When so many animals and plants live among each other, some species are forced to compensate, as to survive the evolutionary arm's race. Venom can be one of these arms, but more like it has always been there for these species, and now it's just a thing that makes them better in some respect than other animals.

When you start to get further and further away from the cold, the climate obviously gets warmer. There are deserts in such parts of the world, obviously. But in deserts again it's more about arachnids like scorpions which are the things venomous there. Snakes too. And these group of animals, again, have already been doing this venom business so long, and have evolved such a way of doing this so early, that now it is just a case of the evolution itself. And these groups of animals like heat (up to a point) and so it is obvious again that there are such venomous animals there. If there is a spot in ecosystem for an animal to fill, it will be filled. These animals have done so. And they happen to be venomous.

As for the other cases of venom and poison, it is again environmental. The Greenland shark is poisonous, not because of it's history as a warm climate species, but because it's environment or it's food supply has made it so.

Australia has  been cut off from the rest of the world, as have many islands. At some point they have been part of some bigger landmass, and most probably in the case of Australia, there has been some parts of it covered in rainforest, so the abundance of species (including the venomous ones) had already been there when it separated. Australia has then had time to create species of it's own, and by chance it just happens to be abundance of venomous animals. 

And of course, most of them are spiders and snakes, which history had already been dictated for quite some time. They had had a long time developing it, and were a long past a point of return in their style of hunting, which necessitated venom in the first place. If food sources and environment should change enough, so should the snakes and spiders. It's evolution.

The same environmental rules and evolution applies to underwater. Coral reefs are the underwater counterparts of jungles. They offer abundant source of food.

Same goes for the coastal waters. Coasts are governed by seasons, by tides, and support different kinds of animals better than say deep ocean.

Where do these venomous jellyfish live? On the coast, on the reefs. Obviously they again have some kind of environmental requirement that forces them to that certain part of the ocean. They developed venom because that is how they hunt and protect themselves. Have you seen these box jellyfishes or the Irukandji? Compared to some deep water cousins of there's, they are like glass.

And as said in the video, truth be told, how much can there be venomous or poisonous animals anyway in the north, if there aren't that big variety of species to begin with? In relation to the limits of diversity, the amount should be tiny.

Evolution has made these animals what they are, and environment and their food force them to be at a certain kind of places, at least for the time being. As already said, these animals haven't gotten time to even try to be somewhere else, or evolve. The history of mankind has been so short, that not enough time has passed for that.

Is it possible that the newly harmless snakes all share a common harmless ancestor that came after their venomous ancestor? (That is, is their closest venomous ancestor so recent that it's possible one split resulted in the non-venomous mutation?) If so, it's possible that from that common ancestor, there was an unrelated mutation that helped the snakes prosper independent of venom.
It might be like saying humans are prosperous because they don't have tails. Homo sapiens don't have tails (because we don't hang out in trees too often and a no-tail mutation wasn't harmful), but it's the other things about humans (such as farming) that led them to civilization.
Or, on that note, perhaps there's some mutation that helped venomous snakes and that made mutations removing venom a non-issue. So perhaps the proliferation of non-venomous snakes has more to do with an earlier mutation that is helping venomous snakes as well, but the effects to venomous snakes as a whole go unnoticed due to the vast amounts of venomous snakes. I would focus on recent snake mutations and common mutations in non-venomous snakes if I wanted to find an answer.

Interesting question. I think your assessment is bit biased by the fact that animals which either hunt vertebrates or use poison to protect against them are the ones with toxins which affect humans. The pre-eminant group which does this are snakes, and they like warm climates because they are reptiles rather than anything to do with their toxin. Spiders are all venomous to insects and, as you say, our sensitivity to funnelweb toxin is a bit of an accident. The redback family is, however, found all over the place including North America where you have black widows. Toxic marine predators, like the Conus Shell, are found in tropical waters but also temperate regions. So leaving aside snakes, I'm not sure there that much of a warm climate bias.

I'd hypothesize that the "success" of losing the venom is that it lessens the likelihood of a snake being killed by the 'new' dominant life form in town, Humans. Just as we've artificially selected cute traits in dogs, we've (at a much slower pace due to lack of attempts at full domestication) artificially selected the non-venomous snakes for survival by not killing them. I'm sure even a Aussie pre-teen can tell you which snakes to defend yourself against and which you can play with and keep as pets (allowing them to bread more often in captivity.)

I have a question.

Time travel is one of my favorite topics! I wrote some time travel stories in junior high school that used a machine of my own invention to travel backwards in time, and I have continued to study this fascinating concept as the years have gone by.

We all travel in time. During the last year, I've moved forward one year and so have you. Another way to say that is that we travel in time at the rate of 1 hour per hour.

But the question is, can we travel in time faster or slower than "1 hour per hour"? Or can we actually travel backward in time, going back, say 2 hours per hour, or 10 or 100 years per hour?

It is mind-boggling to think about time travel. What if you went back in time and prevented your father and mother from meeting? You would prevent yourself from ever having been born! But then if you hadn't been born, you could not have gone back in time to prevent them from meeting.

Albert Einstein
The great 20th century scientist Albert Einstein developed a theory called Special Relativity. The ideas of Special Relativity are very hard to imagine because they aren't about what we experience in everyday life, but scientists have confirmed them. This theory says that space and time are really aspects of the same thing—space-time. There's a speed limit of 300,000 kilometers per second (or 186,000 miles per second) for anything that travels through space-time, and light always travels the speed limit through empty space.

Special Relativity also says that a surprising thing happens when you move through space-time, especially when your speed relative to other objects is close to the speed of light. Time goes slower for you than for the people you left behind. You won't notice this effect until you return to those stationary people.

Say you were 15 years old when you left Earth in a spacecraft traveling at about 99.5% of the speed of light (which is much faster than we can achieve now), and celebrated only five birthdays during your space voyage. When you get home at the age of 20, you would find that all your classmates were 65 years old, retired, and enjoying their grandchildren! Because time passed more slowly for you, you will have experienced only five years of life, while your classmates will have experienced a full 50 years.

Time traveler

So, if your journey began in 2003, it would have taken you only 5 years to travel to the year 2053, whereas it would have taken all of your friends 50 years. In a sense, this means you have been time traveling. This is a way of going to the future at a rate faster than 1 hour per hour.

Time travel of a sort also occurs for objects in gravitational fields. Einstein had another remarkable theory called General Relativity, which predicts that time passes more slowly for objects in gravitational fields (like here on Earth) than for objects far from such fields. So there are all kinds of space and time distortions near black holes, where the gravity can be very intense.

In the past few years, some scientists have used those distortions in space-time to think of possible ways time machines could work. Some like the idea of "worm holes," which may be shortcuts through space-time. This and other ideas are wonderfully interesting, but we don't know at this point whether they are possible for real objects. Still the ideas are based on good, solid science. In all time travel theories allowed by real science, there is no way a traveler can go back in time to before the time machine was built.

I am confident time travel into the future is possible, but we would need to develop some very advanced technology to do it. We could travel 10,000 years into the future and age only 1 year during that journey. However, such a trip would consume an extraordinary amount of energy. Time travel to the past is more difficult. We do not understand the science as well.

Actually, scientists and engineers who plan and operate some space missions must account for the time distortions that occur because of both General and Special Relativity. These effects are far too small to matter in most human terms or even over a human lifetime. However, very tiny fractions of a second do matter for the precise work necessary to fly spacecraft throughout the solar system.

Find out how one NASA mission is doing some very clever space-time experiments to test Einstein's theory of relativity using the International Space Station.

I would think that one reason that snakes evolved to be less venomous is attributed to how they catch prey.  You look at a constrictor snake, its physical mechanisms and strategy to capturing prey reduce the chance of that prey from escaping. Whereas a venomous snake must rely on its venom and jaw strength alone.  And as veritasium stated, a snakes physiology isn't suited to sprint or move too much. So I would think they evolved to use the least amount of energy to capture its prey but with the best chances of success.  Why this might be seen as illogical might be due to our capacity to utilize tools and our surroundings. To us the venom would be seen as an advantage because we could inject an animal from a distance and then track it til it died. Much like how we use different types of tools to accomplish a gool. Snakes obviously have limited comprehension and also are somewhat limited on how it would track its prey at longer distances.

Venom is just protein, you can easily digest it.  It's only dangerous if it makes its way into the bloodstream.

It's more reliant on what the target prey is.  For instance, the reason sea snakes have of the most toxic venoms is because their main prey is cold-blooded fish.  When that specialized venom ends up in a warm-blooded animal, it becomes much more potent.  Prey type is the main indicator.

I think you misunderstood-  he was referring to only a single example.  Mammals are usually just as susceptible to the effects of venom as any other group.  Often, it's the size of the animal that affects the potency of venom (as well as whether the animal is warm or cold blooded in some cases).

Well, human saliva plays a role in breaking down food, it isn't just about digestion.  Spiders, along with many other venomous species, have been around longer than humans so there has been hundreds of millions more years for their salivary glands to change to develop venom. So its not REALLY an advantage for the snake.

I'm afraid you've fallen victim to some propaganda. Evolution isn't about things being *spontaneously* created; it explains the process by which more suitable (for a given environment) species will be those that *remain*. In a friendly enough environment the less suitable ones may do just as well, and the process seemingly halts. For instance, lactose intolerance is widely spread, but there are enough other things to eat that people suffering from that do not die out.

Try reading up on what evolution is. We haven't stopped evolving; we're just not under enough pressure to motivate specific or drastic changes. Also, the neat thing about your admonition to "look thew[sic] creation" is that it doesn't do jack to explain either thing you mention - at most provides an excuse for not even trying to establish any explanation. My theory on loss of venom resulting on success: In evolution the cost/benefits analysis is only a zero sum game over the short term. When a species loses an advantage but still proliferates in say a period where challenges are slight, when challenges become heavier again the new advantages will be in different directions. So a handicap becomes a factor of selection towards other advantages when the environment lacks other limiting factors to induce evolution.

thank you for your great efforts for clarification. What i understand is there no relation between the venom and the skin color. I liked your example. I think this subject deserves to be researched extensively.

- Part 4 -

To sum it up: Although the mechanisms that governs skin pigmentation and absence or presence of venom are entirely distinct from each other, a correlation between them still exists, because certain combinations of traits are beneficial, while different combinations of the very same traits are detrimental to survival.
Chance determines what combinations appear. Natural selection determines what combinations survive.

- Part 3 -

The non-venomous and bright snakes don't get attacked for the next couple of millions of years, but over time, their predators evolve into losing their fear of brightly-pigmented snakes, because the odd mutated owl or fox that is accidentally born without that fear that is part of its species' usual instincts, gets to attack a brightly-pigmented non-venomous snake and live to pass on its mutation. And since colorful snakes are easier to spot than dull ones, they get eaten more often.

- Part 2 -

Now, imagine what would happen to those 100 snakes during the next few years. How many of them would survive and pass on their mutated genes?
The venomous but bright snakes will scare away many of its potential predators. The venomous but dull snakes will not, so they will be attacked more often. Even though they usually kill their attackers, they still become injured more often, and many die from the results of these injuries.

No, the venom doesn't have anything to do with its skin colouration. The mechanism that governs pigmentation is entirely separate.

There is a very thin line dividing poison and toxin.
The way I understand it:
Toxin is a biologically active element that affect cells at very low concentration (enzymes, radioactive elements, chemicals with catalytic effect).
They are not necessary deadly though, just disruptive hence the "intoxication" term.
Poison is something that has a high lethal effect and as Paracelsius said: "All things are poison, only the dose permits something not to be poisonous."
But that's the way I understand it.

Vipers have one nasty venom: it is a hemorrhaging venom which clots the blood.
The venom might not kill you, but it definitely ensures many health complications: blood clots clog up the blood vessels long after, causing tissue to suffocate (which can cause heart attack (AMI/MI), lung failure (PE) and other internal organ failure(LF,KF/RI,RF etc.) , including stroke (CVA)), also blood clots produce dead (suffocated) tissue that can cause all kinds of associated problems (like aseptic necrosis).

My pet theory (before completing video).
In the places where there are more poisonous species, there is less drinkable water. With less water, it becomes an evolutionary advantage to not require as much. The most efficient way to lower your water requirement it to be smaller. Small species have difficulty defending themselves and catching prey. Venom/poison allows a smaller species to mitigate this disadvantage without becoming more water dependent.

The most venomous animals actually do live in hotter countries. This is due to the fact that more cold blooded animals live in these hotter countries, as your said in the video. Cold blooded animals require larger/deadlier doses of venom to be lethal. Because of the increased density of cold blooded animals, there will be more predators of these animals.Thus a larger density of highly venomous animals.

Redbacks are Latrodectus hasseltii but black widows are Latrodectus mactans. Black widows have their red mark on their belly, not their back. Members of the genus Latrodectus are commonly called 'widow spiders' because some species, including the two mentioned, will cannibalise their mates. Because of the world-wide coverage of this genus and the group of toxins in the venom, they have the highest body-count for any spider genus.

Just going to give a little bit of info on the fugu fish. It's a puffer fish that is a delicacy in Japan. It hosts symbiotic bacteria that produce tetrodotoxin (probably, there's some debate), which gets stored in the fish's liver. It has no known antidote, and is very potent, and can be absorbed via inhalation, ingestion, and through cuts. So, basically, if it gets inside the body, it gets to the blood. It kills by paralyzing the diaphragm (respiratory failure).

The number of venomous species corresponds roughly to the biodiversity of an area. The countries that are most diverse or have shared biomes with such a country have the most venomous species. All countries that have high biodiversity but low venom counts are either islands like New Zealand or Madagascar where species colonization is more difficult, or are separated from the diverse biomes of their neighbours by mountains, as with Chile. Evolution is an organism adapting to conditions. Conditions include temp, moisture, food, and everything else. Mutations occur and the animal changes gradually over very long periods of time. Those that are most suited to the environment will do well in that environment typically. I don't think it's a matter of the level of toxicity or what non-prey animals are susceptible but whether the toxins they developed had a marked effect on their ability to survive. It's what worked and nothing more.

Theory: Modern non-venomous snakes have lost their venom due to the effects of  genetic load. Each generation of a population has more and more mutations and corruptions of genes than previous generations, resulting is damaged code, resulting in harmful or non-beneficial characteristics. Severe corruptions may result in unviable individuals (who quickly die), but as a population, the degradation is much slower, because only those with a smaller number of corruptions survive to reproduce.
